awd_titl_txt: A New Paradigm for Spectrum Sharing between Wireless Communications and Radio Astronomy
awd_abstract_narration:
This EARS (Enhancing Access to the Radio Spectrum) program was founded in response to the 2010 Presidential Memorandum on Unleashing the Wireless Broadband Revolution mandated by Congress as part of the National Broadband Plan. It was referenced in 2010 State of the Union and later on the Middle Class Tax Relief and Job Creation Act of 2012 (More than 1/3 of the bill deals with radio spectrum), the PCAST 2012 Report [President's Council of Advisors on Science and Technology] (which calls for vastly increased use of spectrum sharing) and the 2013 Presidential memo (Expanding America's Leadership in Wireless Innovation). The aim of this program is to identify bold new concepts with the potential to contribute to significant improvements in the efficiency of radio spectrum utilization, protection of passive sensing services, and in the ability for traditionally underserved Americans to benefit from current and future wireless-enabled goods and services. The impact is large on the economics of the Nation as seen on the last FCC bidding of 65MHz of the spectrum for over $45 billion early in 2015. It will enable access to science, engineering, industry, civilian and military users of the radio frequency (RF) spectrum.

Active wireless systems (which transmit and receive RF signals) such as cellular wireless communications have generated numerous advancements in our society and tremendous impacts on the national economy. Passive wireless systems (which only receive usually very faint signals) such as radio astronomy and earth exploration remote sensing have provided economically and scientifically important observations of Earth's environment, our solar system and the cosmos (e.g., weather forecasting, observation of solar flares which could affect infrastructure and lives on Earth). Both types of systems play crucial roles for the growth of humanity, thus their advancements need to be accommodated. However, their spectrum requirements are growing and conflicting to a large degree, and radio frequency interference (RFI) from active systems to passive systems is an increasing concern. This calls for a new paradigm of spectrum access and sharing that can cope with the future's needs. This project proposes such a paradigm between cellular wireless communications (CWC) and radio astronomy systems (RAS). 

The project develops a novel time and frequency division spectrum access between CWC and RAS, which not only resolves the spectrum requirement conflict but also enhances spectrum access opportunities for both systems. Instead of relying on the geographical isolation of RAS telescopes to avoid RFI, the project introduces a geographical coexistence paradigm between CWC and RAS through the use of a large number of distributed auxiliary radio telescopes (DARTs). The very large scale DARTs will suppress the RFI issue and potentially enable a quantum leap in RAS's capabilities. In addition, the project develops novel adaptive circuitry and signal processing algorithms to handle the RFI issue efficiently. In brief, this project develops an interdisciplinary and mutually-beneficial technical solution and framework for spectrum access of CWC and RAS through coordination between them. CWC could gain more spectrum access opportunities which will enable more wireless services/applications and new business opportunities, thus expanding and enriching the national economy. RAS will secure more spectrum access opportunities and enhanced astronomical observation capabilities, thus accelerating its contributions to the fundamental science, knowledge of the universe, and protection of lives on Earth through space environmental information.

por.por_cntn:
Radio astronomy studies phenomenological science about the universe as well as astro-physics and astro-chemistry by detecting astronomical signals coming from outer space. As the astronomical signal power is extremely weak, radio astronomy system (RAS) is very vulnerable to radio frequency interference (RFI) from wireless communication systems (WCS).  Thus, RAS telescopes are typically protected by radio quiet zones within which people have no wireless communication/information access ? an undesirable constraint for people living there, especially in this wireless enabled information age. On the other hand, phenomenal growth of WCS and related spectrum allocations have enabled better information access and numerous useful applications for society. However, they also cause less spectrum observation opportunities and greater chances of RFI for RAS, thus hindering science advancement. This project developed a new paradigm of spectrum sharing between WCS and RAS to address the above-mentioned spectrum access conflict between them.

In particular, the following technical solutions were developed:

1) Shared spectrum-access zone (SSAZ) with time-frequency division spectrum access: This solution allows both geographical and spectral co-existence of WCS and RAS as opposed to the existing paradigm of geographical and spectral isolation between WCS and RAS. The project developed i) how to determine a geographical zone for shared spectrum-access around an RAS site, ii) how to design a shared spectrum access scheme with a frame structure consisting of WCS-only time slot (for WCS data transmission), guard time slot (for guarding against propagation delay and for built-in fine tuning), and RAS-only time slot (for RAS observation) in each band while introducing a time offset between the frame beginnings across different bands (for reducing communication latency of WCS), iii) how to exploit time-dependent WCS and RAS data load statistics  to improve spectrum utilization efficiencies for both systems (e.g., more resources allocated to WCS during typical WCS busy traffic durations and to RAS during typical WCS light traffic durations), and iv) how to extend the above concepts to the shared spectrum access scenario between WiFi and RAS by means of coordination and modifying the WiFi medium access protocols.  The numerical performance evaluation results show that while providing substantial guaranteed RFI-free RAS observation opportunities, the new approach?s WCS service provisioning capability within the SSAZ can be quite close to that with solely WCS spectrum access, which has no guaranteed RFI-free RAS observation opportunities.  

2) Distributed auxiliary radio telescopes (DARTs): This solution, built on the above SSAZ based spectrum sharing, introduces several (auxiliary) radio telescopes appropriately located within WCS service areas without needing radio quiet zones. The analytical and numerical performance evaluation results show that signal combining from a large number of DARTs can provide similar or even better RAS performance than a single-dish RAS with radio quiet zone. Combining newly introduced DARTs and the existing RAS can provide even better capability and performance for RAS. The results also reveal that no more than 6-bit ADC is needed for DARTs. In addition, this project also developed a cooling power optimization strategy which exploits variations of ambient temperature of the radio telescope and achieves substantial power saving over the conventional way of setting a fixed cooling temperature for radio telescopes.

3) RFI cancellation in non-linear regime: This solution goes a step further in increasing spectrum utilization efficiency by allowing RFI in the geographical and spectral coexistence paradigm. This strong RFI drives the RAS receiver to operate in a non-linear regime and RFI cancellation in such regime has not been addressed in the literature. This project developed new signal models and then new RFI cancellation and compensation schemes for both single-dish and array RAS systems in non-linear regimes. The numerical performance evaluation results showed the importance of incorporating nonlinearity as well as the promising performance of the developed RFI cancellation and compensation schemes.

The project has provided graduate students training not only from advancing technical skills but also from broadening viewpoints by incorporating various needs such as science/discovery, technology, consumer applications, business, and spectrum policy. In addition, the proposed coexistence paradigm offers several advantages to society, namely much less restriction/relocation of human settlement against RAS sites, more public awareness of radio astronomy and science due to coexistence, and no loss of wireless access opportunities for the society near RAS sites.  It could also influence future spectrum policies for improving spectrum utilization efficiency.
